title.narrative: Upgrading Seaweeds Value Chain in the Philippines

description.narrative: How to optimize the seaweed value chain in the Philippines to increase the income of small-scale fisher folk on the remote Philippine islands of Northern Samar? Seaweed farming is growing into a major economic activity with a high demand on the local and international market. However, the production areas are not sufficient. The project is designed to develop the service market on seaweeds and its position within the private and public market structures.
Seaweed farming an important economic activity

The program focuses on expanding the areas of production and increasing the production volume of dried seaweeds in Northern Samar. The project also introduces the culture of species of less economic value but with greater capacity to combat stress and diseases which can result in a higher volume: Eucheuma denticulatum (spinosum).
The project runs in the coastal municipalities of Northern Samar. SPPI, the local partner organization in this project, closely monitors the seaweed farmers and trains them on the latest developments in the seaweeds industry. By establishing producer organizations and provide training on leadership, project management, savings mobilization, and gender sensitivity, producer organizations are a sustainable possibility for livelihood and skills development. Also, by forming women’s committees, SPPI is empowering women to have a voice in rural and local economic development.
The presence of consolidators (developed through this project) in the villages also helps in encouraging farmers to plant because they can always sell their product without incurring heavy (transportation) costs in bringing the product to the market. SPPI in this case has brought the market to the poor.
The project also aims to build the capacity of the local NGO SPPI to be a microfinance institution (MFI). The SPPI MFI will service the financing requirements of its value chain intervention. This project is being supported to promote the development of the service market on seaweeds in the island municipalities, and improve its position within market structures and its public and private actors.
This project is part of a partnership between ICCO Cooperation South East Asia and SPPIâ€™s Local Economy Development Program (LEDP). The project involves the participation of members of the Samar Island Seaweeds Value Chain Network; the seaweed farmers, academe, Philippine National Police, government agencies like the Bureau of Fisheries and Aquatic Resources, local government, and the NGO SPPI.

title.narrative: Number of Business Development Service providers that have upscaled their services

comment.narrative: SPPI added the following services: 1. provision of seaweed seedlings produced by its own nursery 2. trade facilitation and marketing services 3. provision of in-kind loans for seaweed farmers
There was a 4-month extension but the services remained.

title.narrative: Number of male small producers - connected to emerging, not yet sustainable Producer Organizations - who have improved their income

comment.narrative: The actual target was adjusted to 1000. Additional 325 plans to start planting this March 2017

title.narrative: Number of Business Development Service providers who operate on private sector terms

comment.narrative: The SPPI Seaweed Ventures, Inc. though not yet registered has operated the dry seaweed trading activities for the past 2 years.
The spin off company is not yet operational. All activities are still managed by SPPI, an NGO.

title.narrative: Number of emerging Producer Organization supported towards profitability--sustainability--gender sensitivity

comment.narrative: There were 31 producer organizations in 37 villages in 12 municipalities. 14 organizations were added from Eastern Samar
